body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

$host.privatedata.ErrorForegroundColor = 'DarkGray'  # works as in PowerShell v7.2.4
$host.UI.RawUI.ForegroundColor = "DarkGreen"  # ineffective
[System.Console]::ForegroundColor = 'DarkCyan'  # no longer effective

### Expected behavior

```console
those `ForegroundColor` methods should change the foreground colour, as they did in `PowerShell v7.2.4`
```


### Actual behavior

```console
no change in foreground colour
```


### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
    ----                           -----
    PSVersion                      7.2.6
    PSEdition                      Core
    GitCommitId                    7.2.6
    OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19044
    Platform                       Win32NT
    PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
    PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
    SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
    WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### OS Data

```powershell
Version    Caption
    -------    -------
    10.0.19044 Microsoft Windows 10 Pro
```

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Repro steps:
1. Open the latest PowerShell preview.7, and make sure using the default prompt
2. Run `$ErrorView = 'NormalView'`
3. Run `Write-Error 'error'`

This is a bug introduced by https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/17705.
The `Cosnole.ForegroundColor` and `Console.BackgroundColor` were changed but never set back after writing out the message.

https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/1ee27cf7dffeb0175dc42dcd47c39e1725c91b67/src/System.Management.Automation/FormatAndOutput/DefaultFormatters/PowerShellCore_format_ps1xml.cs#L1299-L1307

### Expected behavior

```console
The prompt after executing `Write-Error 'error'` doesn't have the color changed
```


### Actual behavior

```console
The prompt gets changed to the error color
```


### Error details

```console
N/A
```


### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.3.0-preview.7
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.3.0-preview.7
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19044
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/127450/184422300-f1ebe59e-3cc0-42eb-a393-acdfe6a56bd9.png)

body:
# PR Summary

Change class used for `Get-CimClass` cmdlet's `-Amended` parameter test: `Win32_PrinterConfiguration` for `Win32_LogicalDisk`.

## PR Context

It seems that `Win32_PrinterConfiguration` class isn't the best option for testing the `-Amended` parameter,
because the qualifiers collection for its properties contain Description, Values, etc., even if you don't use the `-Amended` parameter.

In contrast, such classes, like `Win32_LogicalDisk` and others don't contain aforementioned qualifiers when the `-Amended` parameter wasn't specified.


## PR Checklist

- [x] [PR has a meaningful title](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission)

body:
# PR Summary

Fixes a bug that caused an exception for `ParsingTooManyParameterSets` to never be thrown when a command has more than 32 parameter sets.

## PR Context

Due to use of `uint` bitmask for parameter sets lookup, a maximum of 32 parameter sets are allowed in commands/scriptblocks. The intended exception when 33+ sets are defined was never thrown due to a bug, causing an index overflow that registers parameters in set 33 and higher in existing sets.

Fix #9372

## PR Checklist

- [x] [PR has a meaningful title](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission)

### Prerequisites

- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)

- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

- Obtain a MacOS / nix machine
- Create a `.psm1` module and place it in a subfolder under your home `~` directly
- Create a `.ps1` script and attempt to reference the `.psm1` module using the `using module` statement
- Run the script

**Example**
```pwsh
#!/usr/local/bin/pwsh
using module "~/.nuget/packages/<package-name>/1.0.1/scripts/k8s/module.psm1"
```

### Expected behavior

```console
I expected the `using module` statement to successfully load classes from the `.psm1` module
```


### Actual behavior

```console
- I'm receiving an error stating:


The specified module '/Users/<username>/<calling ps1 path>/~/.nuget/packages/<package-name>/1.0.1/scripts/k8s/module.psm1' was not loaded because no valid module file was found in any module directory.
```

- I've verified that the file exists under the `~/.nuget/packages/<package-name>/1.0.1/scripts/k8s/module.psm1'` path
- For some reason the calling script's path and the module's path are getting merged

body:
### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a new scope
2. Create a steppable pipeline and run begin
3. Let that scope be cleaned up by the engine
4. Run process on the pipeline created in step 2
5. The scope in the steppable pipeline is not detached from global

```powershell
function testing { process { Get-Date } }
$pipe = & {
    $pipe = { testing }.GetSteppablePipeline('Internal')
    $pipe.Begin($true)
    return $pipe
}

& { $pipe.Process('some input') }
```

### Expected behavior

Maybe an error message saying that the scope is no longer valid, or even just documentation saying this is results in undefined behavior. Best case scenario, it returns the date.

### Actual behavior

```console
Get-Date:
Line |

     |                               ~~~~~~~~
     | The term 'Get-Date' is not recognized as a name of a cmdlet, function, script file, or executable program.
Check the spelling of the name, or if a path was included, verify that the path is correct and try again.

Suggestion [4,General]: The most similar commands are: Get-Date, Set-Date, Test-Date, Get-Dtc
```

### Checklist

- [x] Verify that [`PowerShell-Native`](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell-Native) has been updated / released as needed.
- [x] Check for `PowerShellGet` and `PackageManagement` release plans.
- [x] Start process to sync Azure DevOps artifacts feed such as modules and NuGet packages.
- [x] Create a private branch named `release/v6.x.x` in Azure DevOps repository.
  All release related changes should happen in this branch.
- [x] Prepare packages
    - [x] Kick off coordinated build.
- [x] Kick off Release pipeline.
    - *These tasks are orchestrated by the release pipeline, but here as status to the community.*
    - [ ] Prepare packages
        - [ ] Sign the RPM package.
        - [ ] Install and verify the packages.
        - [ ] Trigger the docker staging builds (signing must be done).
    - [ ] Create the release tag and push the tag to `PowerShell/PowerShell` repository.
    - [ ] Run tests on all supported Linux distributions and publish results.
    - [ ] Update documentation, and scripts.
        - [ ] Update [CHANGELOG.md](../../CHANGELOG.md) with the finalized change log draft.
        - [ ] Stage a PR to master to update other documents and
              scripts to use the new package names, links, and `metadata.json`.
    - [ ] For preview releases,
      merge the release branch to GitHub `master` with a merge commit.
    - [ ] For non-preview releases,
      make sure all changes are either already in master or have a PR open.
    - [ ] Delete the release branch.
    - [ ] Trigger the Docker image release.
    - [ ] Retain builds.
    - [ ] Update https://github.com/dotnet/dotnet-docker/tree/master/3.0/sdk with new version and SHA hashes for global tool. NOTE: this link is broken!

body:
# PR Summary

ForeEach-Object -Parallel using variable processing walks the script block AST to determine if the using variable was defined in the current scope, and does this by tracking the number of 'ForEach-Object -Parallel' commands in the call chain.
However, the provided script block is different, depending on whether it is passed in as a variable or via parameter binding.

$myScript = '"Hello!"'
1 | ForEach-Object -Parallel ([scriptblock]::Create($myScript))
# Script block Ast does not contain the 'ForEach-Object' command in the call chain

1 | ForEach-Object -Parallel { "Hello!" }
# Script block Ast does contain the 'ForEach-Object' command in the call chain

This change takes into account the two forms of script blocks

## PR Context

Backport of **https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/16564**

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

I have a Rest API Call that is supposed to upload a file.
I keep getting this error
The cmdlet cannot run because the -ContentType parameter is not a valid Content-Type header. Specify a valid Content-Type for -ContentType, then retry.

My header looks like this
`{
  "Content-Disposition": "attachment; filename=Shadow Copy Restore.docx",
  "Authorization": "Bearer ....",
  "Content-Length": "FILE_SIZE",
  "Content-Type": "application/vnd.openxmlformats-officedocument.wordprocessingml.document"
}`

I've tried the content-disposition with and without quotes around the file name.

I've created the body of the request with:
`$body = [System.IO.File]::ReadAllBytes($path)`

Unfortunately the -InFile parameter does not seen to work with this API.
I have also tried a content type of application/octet-stream and get the same results.


### Expected behavior

```console
No error
```


### Actual behavior

```console
The cmdlet cannot run because the -ContentType parameter is not a valid Content-Type header. Specify a valid Content-Type for -ContentType, then retry.
```


### Error details

```console
The cmdlet cannot run because the -ContentType parameter is not a valid Content-Type header. Specify a valid Content-Type for -ContentType, then retry.
To suppress header validation, supply the -SkipHeaderValidation parameter.
```


### Environment data

```powershell
ame                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.5
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.5
OS                             Linux 5.18.13-100.fc35.x86_64 #1 SMP PREEMPT_DYNAMIC Fri Jul 22 14:20:24 UTC 2022
Platform                       Unix
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

_No response_

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

I have a custom (proprietary) module that gets installed as part of every AWS instance we create. When I launch PowerShell and attempt to run a command _for the first time_, the command is found well enough to tab-complete the parameters. I don't experience any problem there. However, when I try to run the command, I get a sequence like this:

```
PS C:\Windows\System32> Build-ArtifactArchive -ArtifactType Customer -Verbose
Build-ArtifactArchive: The term 'Build-ArtifactArchive' is not recognized as a name of a cmdlet, function, script file, or executable program.
Check the spelling of the name, or if a path was included, verify that the path is correct and try again.
PS C:\Windows\System32> Get-Module

ModuleType Version    PreRelease Name                                ExportedCommands
---------- -------    ---------- ----                                ----------------
Manifest   7.0.0.0               Microsoft.PowerShell.Management     {Add-Content, Clear-Content, Clear-Item, Clear-ItemProperty…}
Binary     2.1.0.0               Microsoft.PowerShell.PSReadLine2    {Get-PSReadLineOption, Set-PSReadLineOption, Set-PSReadLineKeyHandler, Get-PSReadLineKeyHandler…}
Manifest   7.0.0.0               Microsoft.PowerShell.Utility        {Add-Member, Add-Type, Clear-Variable, Compare-Object…}
Script     2.1.0                 PSReadLine                          {Get-PSReadLineKeyHandler, Get-PSReadLineOption, Remove-PSReadLineKeyHandler, Set-PSReadLineKeyHandle…
Script     1.0.1353.0            TMCTools                            {Build-ArtifactArchive, Build-ExceptionReport, Build-FolderReport, Build-JobReport…}
Binary     1.0.1353              TMCTools

PS C:\Windows\System32> Remove-Module TMCTools
PS C:\Windows\System32> Build-ArtifactArchive -ArtifactType Customer -Verbose
2022-08-05_09:49:56 No license key was detected.
Exception: Unable to initialize function
```

As you can see, the module is loaded in the session and the command is recognized as an exported command, yet it can't be found. But then simply removing the module from the session and repeating the command (this autoloads it again, right?) works.

Note that the module appears as both Script and Binary. This is because I use PSProtector to compile it to DLL.

### Expected behavior

```console
The command should work on the first invocation via autoload.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
PowerShell says the command cannot be found even though Get-Module shows it is loaded.
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PS C:\Windows\System32> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.5
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.5
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.17763
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

_No response_

### Name of the Distribution

Fedora

### Version of the Distribution

35

### Package Types

RPM

### Processor Architecture

AMD64

### .NET Support

* [.NET Core 3.1][linux-fedora]
* [.NET 6][linux-fedora]

See also: https://github.com/dotnet/core/issues/6446

[linux-fedora]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/install/linux-fedora#supported-distributions

### Distribution Requirements

* [Fedora 35][f35] was released on 2021-11-02 and will be maintained for approximately [13 months][lifecycle].
  * **support ends in December 2022**.
 * Fedora 35 is not an interim release or equivalent.

[f35]: https://docs.fedoraproject.org/en-US/fedora/f35/release-notes/
[lifecycle]: https://docs.fedoraproject.org/en-US/releases/lifecycle/

### Exemption Justification

* No currently Fedora distributions have been tested.
* The last tested version (Fedora 34) has been end-of-life since [2022-06-07][eol].

[eol]: https://docs.fedoraproject.org/en-US/releases/eol/

### Progress

* PowerShell/PowerShell-Docker#686

### For PowerShell Team **ONLY**

- [ ] Docker image created

- [ ] [Lifecycle](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/PowerShell-Docs/blob/staging/reference/docs-conceptual/PowerShell-Support-Lifecycle.md) updated

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Issue: Unexpected result on linux from command: New-PSDrive -Name "shareName" -PSProvider "FileSystem" -Root "\\UNCServerName\FolderPath" -Credential $creds -Scope Global

I originally suspected that this was user error. I did try variations such as inverting the \ to / and using "smb:" as a prepend. They did not work. In searching I found the following that make me wonder if this is user error or a restrictions I did not see in the documentation. I did see this in the documentation which leads me to believe there is a minimum of a documentation deficiency. Example/Reasoning:

-Persist
Indicates that this cmdlet creates a Windows mapped network drive. The Persist parameter is only available on Windows.

The above suggests that all other aspects of the command are transportable. The following show this has been a known issue for a while.
https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/1409 (opened 2016-07-18) - No examples and several signs it is not fixed even after:  joeyaiello added the Resolution-Fixed label on May 23, 2017
https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/6629 (opened 2018-04-11) - Still open. Please note as per others in this thread, the CIFS Mount pre-requisite is not an option for me due to Docker restrictions
https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/6759 (opened 2018-04-27) - Still open. Please note as per others in this thread, the CIFS Mount pre-requisite is not an option for me due to Docker restrictions

If an SMB Mount point turns out to be a pre-requisite, I suggest an update to the documentation. A notice that this is required on Linux due to restrictions. I would prefer finding a way to not require SMB Mounts.

Thank you in advance for your time. Please feel free to reach out to me if there are actions I may try to assist. Please

Command: New-PSDrive -Name "shareName" -PSProvider "FileSystem" -Root "\\UNCServerName\FolderPath" -Credential $creds -Scope Global

Linux Tested Variants:
Command Variant: New-PSDrive -Name "shareName" -PSProvider "FileSystem" -Root "//UNCServerName/FolderPath" -Credential $creds -Scope Global
Command Variant: New-PSDrive -Name "shareName" -PSProvider "FileSystem" -Root "smb:\\UNCServerName\FolderPath" -Credential $creds -Scope Global
Command Variant: New-PSDrive -Name "shareName" -PSProvider "FileSystem" -Root "smb://UNCServerName/FolderPath" -Credential $creds -Scope Global



### Expected behavior

```console

### Actual behavior

Bumps [actions/github-script](https://github.com/actions/github-script) from 3 to 6.
Release notes

Sourced from actions/github-script's releases.

v6.0.0

What's Changed

  • Update default runtime to node16 by @​thboop in actions/github-script#235
  • Update node-fetch by @​joshmgross in actions/github-script#237
  • Update @actions/core to 1.6.0 by @​joshmgross in actions/github-script#238

Breaking Changes

With the update to Node 16 in #235, all scripts will now be run with Node 16 rather than Node 12.

New Contributors

  • @​thboop made their first contribution in actions/github-script#235

Full Changelog: https://github.com/actions/github-script/compare/v5...v6.0.0

v5.1.0

What's Changed

  • Update to latest versions for dev dependencies by @​joshmgross in actions/github-script#204
  • update plugin dependencies by @​PeterNitscheMI in actions/github-script#216
  • Update licenses and use jonabc/setup-licensed in workflow by @​joshmgross in actions/github-script#228

New Contributors

  • @​johan-lindqvist made their first contribution in actions/github-script#201
  • @​ansgarm made their first contribution in actions/github-script#215
  • @​PeterNitscheMI made their first contribution in actions/github-script#216

Full Changelog: https://github.com/actions/github-script/compare/v5.0.0...v5.1.0

v5.0.0

What's Changed

  • Upgrade to the latest version of Octokit by @​joshmgross in actions/github-script#193 (Thanks to @​IronSean for contributing to this fix)

Breaking Changes

As part of this update, the Octokit context available via github no longer has REST methods directly. These methods are available via github.rest.* - https://github.com/octokit/plugin-rest-endpoint-methods.js/releases/tag/v5.0.0

See https://github.com/actions/github-script#breaking-changes-in-v5

Full Changelog: https://github.com/actions/github-script/compare/v4.1.1...v5.0.0

title: Update release pipeline to use Approvals and automate some manual tasks

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

The issue manifests whenever a function contains a block (if, foreach, try,...), which writes some output and then calls `return`. All output from the block is written into the output pipeline, even if the output of the block should be redirected into a variable, or a pipeline inside the function:

```
function x([switch]$p) {
    $null = foreach ($a in @(1)) {
        echo "this should not be visible"
        if ($p) {return}
    }
}
```
```
function y([switch]$p) {
    $null = try {echo "this should not be visible"; if ($p) {return}} catch {}
}
```

### Expected behavior

```console
PS> x
PS> y
PS> x -p
PS> y -p
```


### Actual behavior

```console
PS> x
PS> y
PS> x -p
this should not be visible
PS> y -p
this should not be visible
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.3.0-preview.6
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.3.0-preview.6
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19044
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

_No response_

Release notes

Sourced from peter-evans/create-pull-request's releases.

Create Pull Request v4.0.0

Breaking changes

  • The add-paths input no longer accepts -A as a valid value. When committing all new and modified files the add-paths input should be omitted.
  • If using self-hosted runners or GitHub Enterprise Server, there are minimum requirements for v4 to run. See "What's new" below for details.

What's new

  • Updated runtime to Node.js 16
    • The action now requires a minimum version of v2.285.0 for the Actions Runner.
    • If using GitHub Enterprise Server, the action requires GHES 3.4 or later.

What's Changed

  • README.md: Add word "permissions" to part on GITHUB_TOKEN by @​hartwork in peter-evans/create-pull-request#1082
  • docs: Document how to improve close-and-reopen user experience by @​hartwork in peter-evans/create-pull-request#1084

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you can repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

I think I found a problem installing the npm package with at least X version in PowerShell.

When you run this command in PowerShell 7.2.5 or PowerShell 7.3.0-preview.6:
`npm install "express@>=5.0.0-beta.1"`

Instead of installing express with at least 5.0.0-beta.1 version installs the latest stable version (4.18.1) and redirects the output to a file named "5.0.0-beta.1"

I also tested that in cmd, and it works as expected - express@5.0.0-beta.1 is installed.

### Expected behaviour

```console
`npm install "express@>=5.0.0-beta.1"` should install express@5.0.0-beta.1 or newer version
```


### Actual behaviour

```console
`npm install "express@>=5.0.0-beta.1" installs the latest stable version of express (express@4.18.1 at the time of writing this text)
`npm install "express@>=5.0.0-beta.1" creates a file "5.0.0-beta.1" with the content of npm install output
```


### Error details

```console
In this scenario, PowerShell does not return any error
```


### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.5
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.5
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.22000
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0

For preview:

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.3.0-preview.6
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.3.0-preview.6
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.22000
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

_No response_
title: 'npm install "package-name@>=version"' redirect npm install output to file named 'version'

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

Maybe it even qualifies as a bug but it will likely require a break change to correct it and therefore unlikely being resolved as that.
As with this [Powershell script regex single and double quotes](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/73216245), I have seen similar questions before and dealt with this myself a few times.

The [`-Replace` operator](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_comparison_operators#replacement-with-regular-expressions) un-escapes the first parameter `<regular-expression>` but  doesn't do that the same way for the second `<substitute>` parameter:

```PowerShell
'Example: →' -Replace '\u2192', '\u2190'
```
### Expected:
```PowerShell
Example: ←
```
### Actual:
```PowerShell
Example: \u2190
```

You might workaround this by use double quotes and (inconsistently) use the PowerShell escape syntax (e.g. using a backtick `` ` ``):

```PowerShell
'Example: →' -Replace '\u2192', "`u{2190}"
```

But this will also automatically resolve the dynamic substitution (e.g. `$1` as implied by the warning in the [<strike>Regular</strike> expressions substitutions](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_comparison_operators?view=powershell-7.2#regular-expressions-substitutions) description:

### ⚠️ Warning

The `$` character has syntactic roles in both PowerShell and regular expressions:

> In PowerShell, between double quotation marks, it designates variables and acts as a subexpression operator.
> In Regex search strings, it denotes end of the line.
> In Regex substitution strings, it denotes captured groups. Be sure to either put your regular expressions between single quotation marks or insert a backtick (`` ` ``) character before them.

```PowerShell
'→Example←' -Replace '\u2192(.+)\u2190', '\u2192 $1 \u2190'
```
### Expected:
```PowerShell
→ Example ←
```
### Actual:
```PowerShell
\u2192 Example \u2190
```
To workaround this use double quotes and the *PowerShell* escape syntax which also requires to escape the dollar sign (`$`) in the substitution with a backtick (`` ` ``):
```PowerShell
'→Example←' -Replace '\u2192(.+)\u2190', "`u{2192} `$1 `u{2190}'
```

Which could also be worked around with a longer but more consistent syntax using the [`[Regex]::Unescape` method](https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/api/system.text.regularexpressions.regex.unescape):
```PowerShell
'→Example←' -Replace '\u2192(.+)\u2190', [Regex]::Unescape('\u2192 $1 \u2190')
```

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

Let the `-Replace` operator accept a `[Regex]` type as an actual *regular expression* for the `<Substitution>` and not bluntly convert it to a string.

Wishful thinking:
```PowerShell
'→Example←' -Replace '\u2192(.+)\u2190', [Regex]'\u2192 $1 \u2190'
→ Example ←
```

labels.name: Issue-Enhancement

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

[PeteTheCat.zip](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/files/9245920/PeteTheCat.zip)

The zip file contains 4 files that are used to demonstrate the issue.
PeteThe01.cat is a catalog that contains only one file, Green.dll
Test-FileCatalog works fine when there is one file in the catalog and one file is being tested.

PeteThe02.cat is a catalog that contains two files, Green.dll and Red.dll
Test-FileCatalog fails to validate Green.dll in the PeteThe02.cat file catalog.

I am new to using file catalogs, but this behavior looks incorrect.  If I'm doing something wrong, please indicate how to test one file in a catalog with multiple files.



### Expected behavior

```console
Testing the first catalog with one file works correctly:
a) without specifying any files
PS D:\Learn\TestCat\Test01> Test-FileCatalog -CatalogFilePath .\PeteThe01.cat -Detailed

Status        : Valid
HashAlgorithm : SHA256
CatalogItems  : {[Green.dll, FD16354EE3B868E122FE3154EF06AA5FB561393F867D538F0D1D6BAD4228CA41]}
PathItems     : {[Green.dll, FD16354EE3B868E122FE3154EF06AA5FB561393F867D538F0D1D6BAD4228CA41]}
Signature     : System.Management.Automation.Signature
(this shows that Petethe01.cat only contains one file)


b) The first test using PeteThe01.cat works correctly when specifying a single file to validate:
PS D:\Learn\TestCat\Test01> Test-FileCatalog -CatalogFilePath .\PeteThe01.cat -Detailed -Path .\Green.dll

Status        : Valid
HashAlgorithm : SHA256
CatalogItems  : {[Green.dll, FD16354EE3B868E122FE3154EF06AA5FB561393F867D538F0D1D6BAD4228CA41]}
PathItems     : {[Green.dll, FD16354EE3B868E122FE3154EF06AA5FB561393F867D538F0D1D6BAD4228CA41]}
Signature     : System.Management.Automation.Signature

--------------------------------------------------------------------

Second test using PeteThe02.cat, a catalog which contains two dll's.
First, not specifying any path to Test-FileCatalog shows that PeteThe02.cat is a valid catalog and it contains two dll's:
PS D:\Learn\TestCat\Test02> Test-FileCatalog -CatalogFilePath .\PeteThe02.cat -Detailed

Status        : Valid
HashAlgorithm : SHA256
CatalogItems  : {[Green.dll, FD16354EE3B868E122FE3154EF06AA5FB561393F867D538F0D1D6BAD4228CA41], [Red.dll,
                23B1EE3F3D67F403E092BC88B2BCFCC19087EFCE142A2D071B737F9FF59C5411]}
PathItems     : {[Green.dll, FD16354EE3B868E122FE3154EF06AA5FB561393F867D538F0D1D6BAD4228CA41], [Red.dll,
                23B1EE3F3D67F403E092BC88B2BCFCC19087EFCE142A2D071B737F9FF59C5411]}
Signature     : System.Management.Automation.Signature

-------------------------------------------------------------------
The problem occurs when specifying a path to validate one dll for PeteThe02.cat which contains two dll's:

The expected behavior is that when testing one file in the catalog with two dll's that the status should be valid:
PS D:\Learn\TestCat\Test02> Test-FileCatalog -CatalogFilePath .\PeteThe02.cat -Detailed -Path .\Green.dll

Status        : Valid
```


### Actual behavior

```console
This is the actual behavior that I am observing; when there are two files in the catalog, when I try to validate one file in the catalog the validation fails.  The syntax used is the same syntax for the first test performed where the validation passed when there was only one file in the catalog.


PS D:\Learn\TestCat\Test02> Test-FileCatalog -CatalogFilePath .\PeteThe02.cat -Detailed -Path .\Green.dll

Status        : ValidationFailed
HashAlgorithm : SHA256
CatalogItems  : {[Green.dll, FD16354EE3B868E122FE3154EF06AA5FB561393F867D538F0D1D6BAD4228CA41], [Red.dll,
                23B1EE3F3D67F403E092BC88B2BCFCC19087EFCE142A2D071B737F9FF59C5411]}
PathItems     : {[Green.dll, FD16354EE3B868E122FE3154EF06AA5FB561393F867D538F0D1D6BAD4228CA41]}
Signature     : System.Management.Automation.Signature
```


### Error details

```console
Get-Error did not return anything from the Test-FileCatalog command.
```


### Environment data

```powershell
PS D:\Learn\TestCat\Test01> $psversiontable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.5
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.5
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19044
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

![PeteTheCat01](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9277839/182482062-cb1bff11-5bbd-421e-b719-2c8e2ffe1c3f.png)
![PeteTheCat02](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9277839/182482231-b6a6b48a-3c25-4d70-88f9-4d0b4b45f7d2.png)
![PeteTheCat03](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9277839/182482465-bed5e6ac-95a1-4f23-8003-90cd668cf837.png)

# PR Summary

<!-- Summarize your PR between here and the checklist. -->

Change runtime detection when not provided with explicit `-Runtime` to always use `dotnet --info` and their `Platform OS` and `Architecture`,

Fixes #17801 

## PR Context

<!-- Provide a little reasoning as to why this Pull Request helps and why you have opened it. -->

This fixes runtime detection on Linux, which previously always defaulted to `x64`, even on ARM. This meant that `Start-PSBuild` required explicit `-Runtime linux-arm64`, which `Start-DevPowerShell` did not work at all as it had no option of specifying runtime. Also simplifies Windows and OSX code, delegating detection work to `dotnet` who is the main consumer of `runtime` option anyways.

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

1. create a file in the current directory with a list of newline delimited strings. Here is what mine looks like:
```powershell
PS> cat ./testfile
a
b
c
e
f
g
PS>
```
2. Get the contents of the file and use `select-string` to filter out the letter `d`.
```powershell
PS> Get-Content $file | Select-String -Pattern 'd' -NoEmphasis -NotMatch -Raw
a
b
c
e
f
g
PS>
```
3. Pipe the output to `out-file` to overwrite the same `$file` with the filtered output.
```powershell
PS> Get-Content $file | Select-String -Pattern 'd' -NoEmphasis -Raw -NotMatch | out-file -Path $file 
PS>
```
4. Get the contents of the file.
```powershell
PS> Get-Content $file
```

### Expected behavior

```powershell
PS> Get-Content $file
a
b
c
e
f
g
PS>
```


### Actual behavior

```powershell
PS> Get-Content $file
PS>
```


### Error details

No error was returned.


### Environment data

The bug is experienced on both `7.3.0-preview.6` and `7.2.5`.

```powershell

Name                           Value
----                           -----

PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}

```

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

1. Download ARM64 powershell core 7.2.5 on ARM64 Windows 11 22H2 (22621)
2. Launch pwsh.exe and type "Import-Module PKI"
3. Observe this failure message: "Import-Module: Could not load file or assembly 'Microsoft.CertificateServices.PKIClient.Cmdlets, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null'. Format of the executable (.exe) or library (.dll) is invalid."

### Expected behavior

```console
No error.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Import-Module: Could not load file or assembly 'Microsoft.CertificateServices.PKIClient.Cmdlets, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null'. Format of the executable (.exe) or library (.dll) is invalid.
```


### Error details

```console

body:
<!-- Anything that looks like this is a comment and can't be seen after the Pull Request is created. -->

# PR Summary

In the case of HTML content, the cmdlet searches for `<meta charset=...>` in the body to find the right encoding to use.  It uses a regex to do this, however, it applies it to the entire body (which can be quite large).  The `<meta>` tag exists in the `<head>` tag which is expected at the top of the document under `<html>`.  So the change here is to limit the search to just the first 1k characters.  It is possible (since HTML is pretty lenient) to have a bunch of HTML comment tags that pushes the `<meta>` tag much lower, but seems unlikely.  The encoding defaults to UTF-8 which is used by most websites anyways.

Tested manually against the repro in the issue which returns immediately after the payload is downloaded.

## PR Context

Fix https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/17762

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

**The following works:**

main.ps1
```
Write-Host "Script started."

[string[]]$objects = @("one", "two")

$job = $objects | ForEach-Object -Parallel {
    Write-Host "Executing [$_]."
    .\job.ps1 -SomeInput $_
} -ThrottleLimit 5 -AsJob

$job | Receive-Job -Wait

Write-Host "Script finished."
```

job.ps1
```
using module .\modules\testmodule.psm1

param (
    [string]$SomeInput
)

Write-Host "Executing job script [$SomeInput]."

[TestClass]$test = [TestClass]::new("test")
$test.TestMethod1($SomeInput)
```

testmodule.psm1
```
class TestClass {
    [string]$Test

    TestClass(
        [string]$_test
    ) {

        $this.Test = $_test
    }

    [void] TestMethod1([string]$someInput) {
        Write-Host "Method 1: [$someInput]."

        $this.TestMethod2()
    }

    [void] TestMethod2() {
        Write-Host "Method 2."
    }
}
```

Output
```
Script started.
Executing [one].
Executing [two].
Executing job script [two].
Executing job script [one].
Method 1: [one].
Method 1: [two].
Method 2.
Method 2.
Script finished.
```

-------------------------------------

**The following does not work:**
main.ps1
```
using module .\modules\testmodule.psm1

Write-Host "Script started."

[TestClass]$test = [TestClass]::new("test")
[string[]]$objects = @("one", "two")

$job = $objects | ForEach-Object -Parallel {
    Write-Host "Executing [$_]."
    .\job.ps1 -TestClass $using:test -SomeInput $_
} -ThrottleLimit 5 -AsJob

$job | Receive-Job -Wait

Write-Host "Script finished."
```

job.ps1
```
using module .\modules\testmodule.psm1

param (
    [TestClass]$TestClass,
    [string]$SomeInput
)

Write-Host "Executing job script [$SomeInput]."

$TestClass.TestMethod1($SomeInput)
```

testmodule.psm1
```
class TestClass {
    [string]$Test

    TestClass(
        [string]$_test
    ) {

        $this.Test = $_test
    }

    [void] TestMethod1([string]$someInput) {
        Write-Host "Method 1: [$someInput]."

        $this.TestMethod2()
    }

    [void] TestMethod2() {
        Write-Host "Method 2."
    }
}
```

Output
```
Script started.
Executing [one].
Executing [two].
Executing job script [one].
Executing job script [two].
Method 1: [one].
```

There is no error, the script does not terminate, it just hangs.

### Expected behavior

```console
Both approaches should work.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
When using the instance from outside `ForEach-Object -Parallel` the script does not complete and just hangs.
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
Windows 11
PowerShell 7.2.5
```


### Visuals

_No response_

labels.name: Issue-Bug

# PR Summary

Adds a type accelerator for `[ordered]`-> `[OrderedDictionary]` to enables use of `-is`, `-as` and `[ordered]::new()`.

Special `OrderedAttribute` parser-logic that limits it to only allow cast from hash-literal when used like `[ordered]$myVar` is kept per WG-decision, see comment in related issue.

## PR Context

title: Add test for default LanguageMode using remoting

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

In a local git repo with a remote setup on *Windows*:

```
> @{foo=1;bar=2} | Format-Table; git ls-remote --head origin;  @{foo=1;bar=2} | Format-Table #all output property colored
> @{foo=1;bar=2} | Format-Table; $_x = git ls-remote --head origin;  @{foo=1;bar=2} | Format-Table #second output garbled
```
### Notes
- does not reproduce when running in WSL/Ubuntu 20.04
- does not reproduce using "ui" git commands (ie `branch`) - so may have something to do with how git "plumbing" commands are implemented on Windows?

### Expected behavior

```console
All color coded output to be rendered
```


### Actual behavior

```console
After output capture of `git ls-remote...` color is no longer rendered
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.5
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.5
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.22000
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28011906/181789208-1d225474-ec2f-4dd2-ada7-944122f3d31a.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28011906/181789436-c59fa142-85f5-4d34-93c6-94249c3af0fd.png)

labels.description: The issue author needs to provide repro steps.
labels.name: Needs-Repro

title: Capture output of `git ls-remote` on Windows breaks further ANSI color output

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Run `Start-PSBuild` without `-Runtime` on Linux ARM, e.g. Raspberry Pi. It will successfully build, but throw a cryptic error when you try to run `pwsh`. This also breaks `Start-DevPowerShell`, as it tries always tries to run x64, even on ARM.

### Expected behavior

```console
Runs `dotnet publish --runtime linux-arm64`
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Runs `dotnet publish --runtime linux-x64`
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value                                                                                                                                                                            
----                           -----                                                                                                                                                                            
PSVersion                      7.2.4                                                                                                                                                                            
PSEdition                      Core                                                                                                                                                                             
GitCommitId                    7.2.4                                                                                                                                                                            
OS                             Linux 5.15.0-1011-raspi #13-Ubuntu SMP PREEMPT Thu Jun 2 11:44:34 UTC 2022                                                                                                       
Platform                       Unix                                                                                                                                                                             
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}                                                                                                                                                            
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3                                                                                                                                                                    
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1                                                                                                                                                                          
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

_No response_

labels.description: The issue is fixed.
labels.name: Resolution-Fixed

title: `Start-PSBuild -Runtime` always defaults to x64 on Linux

<!-- Anything that looks like this is a comment and can't be seen after the Pull Request is created. -->

# PR Summary
Fixes https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/17653
Instead of looking for a parameter with the exact location specified, it instead looks for the parameter with a position closest to the specified location. This fixes completion for positional parameters where an earlier positional parameter has been specified by name so the completion should look for the next positional parameter.

title: Fix bug in tools/install-powershell.ps1

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

```PowerShell
Get-ChildItem -Path $null
```

### Expected behavior

Some kind of error similar to other *Item CmdLets when Path is $null

```PowerShell
Remove-Item -Path $null
Remove-Item: Cannot bind argument to parameter 'Path' because it is null.
```

Looking at [the source](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/7dc4587014bfa22919c933607bf564f0ba53db2e/src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Management/commands/management/GetChildrenCommand.cs#L218) this is not unexpected, but it can have some unexpected consequences.

Consider the following:
I have two folders setup like this:

```PowerShell
C:\temp\saveeverythinghere> Get-ChildItem

    Directory: C:\temp\saveeverythinghere

Mode                 LastWriteTime         Length Name
----                 -------------         ------ ----
-a---          2022-07-28    15:08              0 SaveEverythingHere1.txt
-a---          2022-07-28    15:08              0 SaveEverythingHere2.txt
-a---          2022-07-28    15:08              0 SaveEverythingHere3.txt

C:\temp\saveeverythinghere> Get-ChildItem ..\deleteme\

    Directory: C:\temp\deleteme

Mode                 LastWriteTime         Length Name
----                 -------------         ------ ----
-a---          2022-07-28    15:08              0 DeleteMe1.txt
-a---          2022-07-28    15:08              0 DeleteMe2.txt
-a---          2022-07-28    15:08              0 DeleteMe3.txt
```
Now run this code:

```PowerShell
$ScanExtensions = '.ps3'
$PathToDeleteFilesFrom = 'C:\temp\deleteme'

# This whill return 0 files
$ScanFiles = Get-ChildItem $PathToDeleteFilesFrom -File -Recurse | Where-Object -Property Extension -in $ScanExtensions

# This will now remove _all_ files in $PWD
Get-ChildItem $ScanFiles.FullName | Remove-Item
```

(In this very hypothetical scenario we can solve it using `Set-StrictMode -Version 7.2` to get `$ScanFiles.FullName` to throw an error, but I still think it's unexpected.)



### Actual behavior

```console
Get-ChildItem -Path '.'
```



### Environment data

```powershell
PSVersion                      7.2.5
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.5
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.22622
```


### Visuals

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17783007/181513530-8e79903f-4f63-42cc-a02e-15a37dfe922c.png)

```powershell
pwsh -NonInteractive -Command { $host.EnterNestedPrompt() }

pwsh -NonInteractive -Command { $host.UI.PromptForChoice( 'caption', 'msg', @('a', 'b'), 0 ) }
```
```console
MethodInvocationException: Exception calling "PromptForChoice" with "4" argument(s): "PowerShell is in NonInteractive mode. Read and Prompt functionality is not available."
```

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Hi all.
We have been banging out heads against PowerShell 7/Terminal windows on server 2022 and Win11 that simply do not type when keystrokes are entered.  
This happens exclusively when trying to type in a PowerShell window, running on Server 2022/Win11 Desktop or RemoteApp via AVD or RDS WebClient.  This happens even when running PS with in a cmd.exe session.
Note - this happens in 5.1 as well for reference.

All input except PowerShell is working correctly.

This is me typing to a PowerShell 7/Terminal window via RDS/AVD using webclient.  There is no input.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/72078919/181193356-d358a0b7-aaae-4e97-90b1-772c7cb6e193.png)

This is me typing to the same window via RDS/AVD not by webclient.  RDP works fine.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/72078919/181191068-ddb0619c-dc0d-4621-991b-2aeac2a806c9.png)

### Expected behavior

```console
Typing in PowerShell 7/Terminal should be reflected in the PS window
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Typing in PowerShell 7/Terminal is not reflected in the PS window
```


### Error details

```console
No errors or feedback of any kind
```


### Environment data

```powershell
$PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.5
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.5
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.20348
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

_No response_

# PR Summary
This PR adds minimum token permissions for the GITHUB_TOKEN in GitHub Actions workflows using https://github.com/step-security/secure-workflows.

<!-- Summarize your PR between here and the checklist. -->

## PR Context

GitHub recommends defining minimum GITHUB_TOKEN permissions for securing GitHub Actions workflows 
- https://github.blog/changelog/2021-04-20-github-actions-control-permissions-for-github_token/  
- https://docs.github.com/en/actions/security-guides/automatic-token-authentication#modifying-the-permissions-for-the-github_token
- The Open Source Security Foundation (OpenSSF) [Scorecards](https://github.com/ossf/scorecard) treats not setting token permissions as a high-risk issue 

This project is part of the top 100 critical projects as per OpenSSF (https://github.com/ossf/wg-securing-critical-projects), so fixing the token permissions to improve security.

Before the change:
`GITHUB_TOKEN` has `write` permissions for multiple scopes, e.g. 
https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/runs/7530874225?check_suite_focus=true#step:1:19

After the change:
`GITHUB_TOKEN` will have minimum permissions needed for the jobs. 

Signed-off-by: Varun Sharma <varunsh@stepsecurity.io>

# PR Summary

<!-- Summarize your PR between here and the checklist. -->

`HelpCultureNotSupported` is caught and ignored with implicit culture (`-UICulture` not given explicitly, defaults to system) to allow trying again with culture's parents. It does not however check if there are any more fallbacks, so all errors of this type are completely silenced. I store first error of this type, then show it if none of the fallbacks succeed,

Fixes #17696 

## PR Context

<!-- Provide a little reasoning as to why this Pull Request helps and why you have opened it. -->

`Update-Help` with implcit culture fails silently on non-US systems (`en-GB` in my case), with no feedback on what is wrong even when using `-Verbose`. With this fix, the user is shown the same error as with explicit `-UICulture (Get-UICulture)`, which clearly describes what they should do:

```powershell
Update-Help: Failed to update Help for the module(s) '...' with UI culture(s) {en-GB} : No UI culture was found that matches the following pattern: en-GB. Verify the pattern and then try the command again..
English-US help content is available and can be installed using: Update-Help -UICulture en-US.
```

## PR Checklist

- [x] [PR has a meaningful title](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission)

# PR Summary

<!-- Summarize your PR between here and the checklist. -->
Enable Dependabot for GitHub Actions.

## PR Context

<!-- Provide a little reasoning as to why this Pull Request helps and why you have opened it. -->
This repository already uses Dependabot but not for GitHub Actions used in workflows.

I see some old (major) versions used in various workflows, with CodeQL v1 being probably the most important one because it will be deprecated in December.
https://github.blog/changelog/2022-04-27-code-scanning-deprecation-of-codeql-action-v1/
